required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Microneedling With Low Energy Laser in Androgenic Alopecia Patients.
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Microneedling With Low Energy Laser in Androgenic Alopecia Patients.

lead_sponsor.agency: Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital

clinical_study.source: Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital

brief_summary.textblock:
Androgenetic alopecia is the most common type of hair loss in men, and affects approximately 50 percent of Caucasian men by age 50. The condition is characterized by the progressive loss of terminal hairs on the scalp in a characteristic distribution. The anterior scalp, mid scalp, temporal scalp, and vertex of the scalp are typical sites of involvement. "Male balding" and "male pattern hair loss" are additional terms used to refer to this condition.
The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of microneedling in androgenic alopecia

primary_outcome.measure: hair regrowth(7-point rating scale (-3 = greatly decreased, -2 = moderately decreased, -1 = slightly decreased, 0 = no change, +1 = slightly increased, +2 = moderately increased, +3 = greatly increased).)
primary_outcome.description: hair regrowth(7-point rating scale (-3 = greatly decreased, -2 = moderately decreased, -1 = slightly decreased, 0 = no change, +1 = slightly increased, +2 = moderately increased, +3 = greatly increased).)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- androgenic alopecia patients
Exclusion Criteria:
- infection, immune disorder, other dermatosis in treating areas
